title: Exclusive: OpenAI Used Kenyan Workers on Less Than $2 Per Hour to Make ChatGPT Less Toxic

last_post.content:
ChatGPT gets treated like technological magic, but that ignores the humans behind the curtain that make it function.

OpenAI paid Sama to hire Kenyan workers at $1.32 to $2 an hour to review “child sexual abuse, bestiality, murder, suicide, torture, self harm, and incest” content. Their work made the tool less toxic, but left them mentally scarred. The company ended the contract when they found out TIME was digging into their practices.

https://time.com/6247678/openai-chatgpt-kenya-workers/

#tech #chatgpt #ai

title: Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #218 - I asked Chat GPT to write a song in the style of Nick Cave and this is what it produced. What do you think?   Verse 1:  In the depths of the night, I hear a call  A voice that echoes, through the hall  It’s a siren’s song, that pulls me in  Takes me to a place, where I can’t begin   Chorus:  I am the sinner, I am the saint  I am the darkness, I am the light  I am the hunter, I am the prey  I am the devil, I am the savior   Verse 2:  I walk the streets, with my head held high  I’ve got my demons, but I’ll make them fly  I’ll dance with the devil, and I’ll play his game  I’ll be the one, to call his name   Chorus:  I am the sinner, I am the saint  I am the darkness, I am the light  I am the hunter, I am the prey  I am the devil, I am the savior   Bridge:  I’ve got the blood of angels, on my hands  I’ve got the fire of hell, in my eyes  I’m the king of the abyss, I’m the ruler of the dark  I’m the one that they fear, in the shadows they hark   Chorus:  I am the sinner, I am the saint  I am the darkness, I am the light  I am the hunter, I am the prey  I am the devil, I am the savior   Outro:  So come with me, to the edge of the night  Where the darkness and the light collide  We’ll walk the line, between the good and the bad  And we’ll see, who comes out on top in the end.

On the subject of young people being nostalgic for things they never experienced, something I learned about recently that I found particularly interesting was this:

Some gen Z'ers learned that back in the day we had small web sites which tended to end in ~myusername.

They re-created some of those spaces, and refer to them as 'tilde clubs' (after the first one). Tiny little self-contained social spaces, often using minimal HTML and terminal access.

http://tilde.club

Here's the first iteration of the syllabus for this semester's " Introduction to Digital Humanities
Part II: Computational Approaches to Culture." Surprised that there aren't too many TBAs. You may find a few things of interest:

a) The final paper will be co-written with AI.
b) There's a midterm exam whose sole purpose in life is to use it as a tool to build vocab and understanding.
c) I set up a binary between Analysis and Poesis that, spoiler alert, I will undermine during the semester.
d) I barely teach coding. Instead I spend a lot of teaching energy on how to read tutorials and corpus analysis papers.

Tagging @laurenfklein and @zoeleblanc who are going on a similar journey this semester too.

http://teaching.elotroalex.com/s23-intro-dh/

I've heard that a newspaper in my own state bowdlerized the text of Dr. King's "I Have a Dream" speech in order to print it.

Though this makes me angry, it's at least a testament to the power that his words had, and still have.

Every year on MLK day, I read "Letter from a Birmingham Jail" in full, it's my favorite of his writing: https://www.csuchico.edu/iege/_assets/documents/susi-letter-from-birmingham-jail.pdf

Celebrate the holiday by reading something he wrote or spoke, in full, and considering the power of his words and actions.

The WikiJournal of Science is a Wikipedia Foundation initiative designed, in part, to bring more academic expertise into Wikipedia.
It's also a full-fledged academic journal and I think is the most transparent journal I've ever come across. For example, even the process to vet me as an editor is transparent: https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/Talk:WikiJournal_of_Science/Editors/Archive_2022#Associate_editor_application_of_Alex_O._Holcombe (yes I am now an associate editor! 😀).

title: The Real Left Wing vs Right Wing Debate

last_post.content:
I missed this essay when it came out but it’s about the debate around institutions and the two sides - “brokenists” and “status-quoists” - that don’t neatly hew to partisan divisions but rather split along a perception of whether institutions can be saved or need to be fundamentally rethought. I think it’s too charitable to “brokenists,” who IMO offer little beyond complaint, but I’m equally displeased w/the status quo.

https://www.tabletmag.com/sections/news/articles/brokenism-alana-newhouse

The yearly ritual of twisting Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s words to defend the status quo is in full swing on #MLKday.

One place it's especially obvious: the Bangor Daily News reprinted #MLK's speech.

But quietly toned it down.

Took out the *inconvenient* bits.

Folks noticed & called it out.

So I decided to do a text compare.

Look closely at what was removed.

The full, original speech is here:
https://www.npr.org/2010/01/18/122701268/i-have-a-dream-speech-in-its-entirety

Hi. I have a game for you.

To play, you draw a category card, such as “ROUND THINGS.” Then, you must shout words from that category, but they must start with a particular letter on the race track. So if your character stands on the letter B, you must shout a ROUND THING that starts with B, such as "balloons" or "butts." You move forward on the race track to another letter when you get one right.

It's sort of like Nascar but with useless knowledge.

https://bit.ly/3we3Ivj
-Oats

title: China’s Population Falls, Heralding a Demographic Crisis

last_post.content:
Is Population falling is a "Demographic Crisis"?

NYtimes says so: Population Falls in China, Heralding a Demographic Crisis

but is it? 3 billion when I was born-- plenty. Yes, lots of older people, but "Demographic Crisis"?

What if we wanted to optimize something other than GDP? habitable planet, say.

Or my favorite to optimize: "Median standard of living" I would think that not having as many people would help on this measure.

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/16/business/china-birth-rate.html

title: Chapter 2 Error control | Improving Your Statistical Inferences

last_post.content: If you repeatedly perform a hypothesis test when the null hypothesis is true, p-values will randomly drift between 0 and 1, and therefore, if you test often enough, you will always find a significant effect. https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/errorcontrol.html#optionalstopping This is why preregistration is important. You can test multiple times as data comes in, but then you need to adjust the alpha level: https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/sequential.html For a single simulation of the p-values you could get, see:

title: Bringing informative priors into your experiment: Bayesian impact evaluation

last_post.content: For a long time I've wanted to try out Bayesian impact evaluation, by formally eliciting priors from policymakers, academics, and program recipients, and then incorporating these into the analysis. A new working paper with Rachael Meager and Leo Iacovone details how we did this with an export promotion program in Colombia, and shows when this gives similar results to frequentist analysis, and where it adds value. A blog summary (and link to the paper) is now up: https://blogs.worldbank.org/impactevaluations/bringing-informative-priors-your-experiment-bayesian-impact-evaluation

title: Wellcome Trust and the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative Partner with DataCite to Build the Open Global Data Citation Corpus

last_post.content: A very welcome initiative from @datacite supported financially by the Wellcome Trust and with tech from ChanZuckerberg: building a Open Global Data Citation Corpus, CC0. https://blog.datacite.org/data-citation-corpus-announcement-2023/ This will help not becoming dependent on big corporate publishers for this data. It promises not to be limited to life sciences.

title: Preprint review should form part of PhD programmes and postdoc training

last_post.content:
The idea that 'institutions could build their own platforms for students’ preprint reviews' is very good. I'd love to see institutions doing more to support and maintain preprint communities.

Each community could collaboratively review/annotate selected preprints and maintain a record of all their reviews work with added commentary on subsequent revisions. I'm sure this is already happening in places but it's a good way of adding context to the literature.

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00085-2

title: Tesla video promoting self-driving was staged, engineer testifies

last_post.content:
wow...

"A 2016 video that Tesla used to promote its self-driving technology was staged to show capabilities like stopping at a red light and accelerating at a green light that the system did not have, according to testimony by a senior engineer.

The video carries a tagline saying: “The person in the driver’s seat is only there for legal reasons. He is not doing anything. The car is driving itself."

https://www.reuters.com/technology/tesla-video-promoting-self-driving-was-staged-engineer-testifies-2023-01-17/

TIL about the "Zero one infinity" rule from a post by @estark.

This definitely comes up often in standard library design and security decisions: if you can't argue why a cutoff should be at a specific value, it might not make sense to have the cutoff. Workloads and machines are so varied, that there is no one-size-fit-all.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_one_infinity_rule

title: New features in dplyr 1.1.0, and an introduction to ivs

last_post.content:
dplyr 1.1.0 is coming very soon!

I recently spoke about it (and the ivs 📦) at the Charlotte #rstats User Group. This presentation highlights a number of exciting new features, including:

- Per-operation grouping with `.by`
- Join enhancements, like inequality joins, rolling joins, and overlap joins
- New functions like `consecutive_id()` and `case_match()`

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9LAML4Nr1II

"The notions of relevance, usefulness, & trustworthiness with respect to information were already overloaded & often difficult to articulate, study, or implement. Newly surfaced proposals that aim to use large language models to generate relevant information for a user’s needs pose even greater threat to transparency, provenance, & user interactions in a search system."

title: The Case of the Golden Idol

last_post.content:
If you liked Return of the Obra Dinn, and especially if you were into it but it was maybe a little too much detective work for you to keep track of, I highly highly recommend The Case of the Golden Idol. It's a detective game where you investigate crime scenes and try to reconstruct what happened, similar to Obra Dinn's filling out of the ship manifest through inference. But the puzzles are a little smaller scope, and it's all 2D. It is SO GOOD.

https://www.thegoldenidol.com/

title: Websites Selling Abortion Pills Are Sharing Sensitive Data With Google

last_post.content:
ProPublica used Blacklight (https://themarkup.org/blacklight) to show that nine online abortion pill providers are sharing sensitive data with Google: https://www.propublica.org/article/websites-selling-abortion-pills-share-sensitive-data-with-google

The off-the-shelf e-commerce tools aren't built for privacy, and patients face new legal risks since overturn of Roe v Wade.

In July, Dara Kerr and I found online abortion pill provider Hey Jane sending visitor data to Meta, Google and others (now stopped), and found a reviewer's personal information: https://themarkup.org/pixel-hunt/2022/07/01/online-abortion-pill-provider-hey-jane-used-tracking-tools-that-sent-visitor-data-to-meta-google-and-others
